entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 9 at 1:32AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
Showers will continue to dump heavy rainfall across the area. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches have already fallen, and additional rainfall amounts of up to 1 to 2 inches are possible through the early morning hours.
HAZARD...Heavy rain.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Heavy rain may cause temporary street flooding especially in poor drainage areas.
Locations impacted include... Lumpkin, Buena Vista, Butler, Ellaville, Roberta, Cusseta, Preston, Richland, Reynolds, Ideal, Putnam, Brantley, Seminole, La Crosse, Oakland, Sanford, Howard, Eelbeck/West Fort Moore, Bumphead, and Horns.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Taylor; Crawford; Chattahoochee; Marion; Schley; Macon; Stewart; Webster; Sumter

cap:parameter.value: Heavy showers will continue to impact portions of western Macon, Marion, Chattahoochee, Stewart, central Webster, southwestern Crawford, Schley, northwestern Sumter and Taylor Counties through 215 AM EST

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued March 9 at 12:27AM CST until March 9 at 7:00AM CST by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
FFWTAE
The National Weather Service in Tallahassee has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Coffee County in southeastern Alabama... Dale County in southeastern Alabama... Henry County in southeastern Alabama...
* Until 700 AM CST Saturday.
* At 1227 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Elba, Abbeville, Fort Gaines, Ozark, Fort Novosel, Enterprise, Newton, New Brockton, Ariton, Lee, Newville, Dill, Dale County Lake, Beamon, Arguta, Marley Hill, Dillard, Mabson, Blackwell Field A/p and Skipperville.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coffee, AL; Dale, AL; Henry, AL

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 9 at 4:25PM ChST until March 12 at 8:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY CONDITIONS WILL CAUSE HIGH FIRE THREAT...
The National Weather Service in Tiyan has issued a Fire Weather Watch, which is in effect from 10 AM Monday morning through 8 PM Tuesday evening.
* WIND...East wind 15 to 25 mph with gusts around 30 mph, especially in higher elevations.
* HUMIDITY...50 to 60 percent during the day.
* IMPACTS...any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE MONDAY MORNING THROUGH EARLY TUESDAY EVENING FOR GUAM

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 9 at 12:11AM CST until March 9 at 3:15AM CST by NWS Mobile AL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Portions of Alabama, including the following counties, Baldwin, Conecuh, Covington, Crenshaw and Escambia and northwest Florida, including the following county, Escambia.
* WHEN...Until 315 AM CST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1211 AM CST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Andalusia, Bay Minette, Atmore, Brewton, Stockton, McCullough, East Brewton, River Falls, Castleberry, Red Level, Dozier, Heath, Gantt, I65 And AL 113, I65 And AL 21, Bratt, I65 And CR 1, Poarch Creek Reservation, Kirkland and London. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 9 at 12:08AM CST until March 10 at 12:43AM CST by NWS Birmingham AL
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Birmingham AL has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Alabama...
Tallapoosa River At Wadley affecting Tallapoosa, Chambers and Randolph Counties.
.Heavy rainfall has fallen across the Tallapoosa River Basin and a flood warning is now in effect for the Tallapoosa River Basin.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Tallapoosa River at Wadley.
* WHEN...Tonight through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Flooding of pasture lands in the area occurs and cattle and farm equipment should be moved to higher ground if higher stages are forecast.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 PM CST Friday the stage was 12.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early this morning to a crest of 14.1 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage this afternoon. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chambers, AL; Randolph, AL; Tallapoosa, AL

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 9 at 12:37AM EST until March 10 at 8:38PM EDT by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia... Alabama...
Chattahoochee River at 14th Street at Columbus affecting Russell, Lee, Chattahoochee and Muscogee Counties.
For the Chattahoochee River Basin...including Helen, Dahlonega, Cornelia, Buford, Buford, Suwanee, Suwanee, Chattahoochee River upstream McGinnis Ferry Rd, Norcross, Chattahoochee River above Roswell, Roswell, Powers Ferry & I285 Atlanta, Smyrna, Chattahoochee River below Morgan Falls Dam, Atlanta, Atlanta, Atlanta, Atlanta, Fairburn, Whitesburg, Fairplay, Whitesburg, Whitesburg, Franklin, Corinth, Hammett Rd below Hogansville, Franklin, West Point, Columbus, Union, Omaha...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Chattahoochee River at 14th Street at Columbus.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 30.0 feet, Minor flooding continues along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the 14th Street bridge. Large portions of the River Walk in Columbus will be flooded up to 3 feet deep. The water level reaches the top of the boat ramp behind the Columbus Convention and Trade Center. The Phenix City Amphitheater in Alabama will be flooded up to two feet deep. Portions of the River Walk in Phenix City will begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 AM EST Saturday /11:30 PM CST Friday/ the stage was 27.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:30 AM EST Saturday /11:30 PM CST Friday/ was 27.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 29.5 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon to 24.0 feet early Monday afternoon. It will rise to 24.2 feet early Tuesday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 27.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 29.6 feet on 03/05/1934. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lee, AL; Russell, AL; Chattahoochee, GA; Muscogee, GA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 9 at 12:23AM EST until March 11 at 9:24AM EDT by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Big Creek near Alpharetta affecting Forsyth and Fulton Counties.
For the Big Creek...including Alpharetta...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Big Creek near Alpharetta.
* WHEN...Until late Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Minor flooding continues to expand further into the woodlands and fields along the creek from near Cumming in south Forsyth County to Alpharetta and Roswell in north Fulton County. Additional portions of The Big Creek Greenway have minor flooding with 1 to 2 feet of water. Most of the walking and biking paths will be closed...especially upstream and downstream from the gage on Kimball Bridge Road and near Rock Mill Park. Portions of the YMCA Campground off Preston Ridge Road will flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:00 AM EST Saturday the stage was 5.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 8.2 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage early Monday morning. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.2 feet on 12/27/2023. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued March 9 at 12:17AM EST until March 9 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to one half foot of inundation above ground level in low lying areas due to tidal flooding. For the Coastal Flood Watch, one to two feet of inundation above ground level possible in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 7 AM EST this morning, especially around the time of high tide. For the Coastal Flood Watch, from this afternoon through Sunday morning, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, water reaches the floor of the Maritime Museum in Annapolis, begins to cover Bowyer Road on the Naval Academy campus, and numerous businesses on Dock Street are flooded, along with the City Dock parking lot.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides up to 3 feet above normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 3:46 AM and 4:39 PM.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST THIS MORNING... ...COASTAL FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH SUNDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 8 at 11:31PM EST until March 12 at 6:30PM EDT by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Georgia...
Flint River at US 19 near Carsonville affecting Upson, Talbot, Crawford and Taylor Counties.
For the Flint River Basin...including Lovejoy, Americus, Peachtree City, Fayetteville, Peachtree City, Woolsey, Sharpsburg, Peachtree City, Peachtree City, Senoia, Griffin, Orchard Hill, Griffin, Molena, Thomaston, Carsonville, Montezuma, Byromville...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Flint River at US 19 near Carsonville.
* WHEN...From Saturday morning to Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 25 feet, Moderate flooding begins. Access Road to boat ramp and parking lot to boat ramp flood. In addition... flooding of most of the land at the bend of the river upstream develops.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:45 PM EST Friday the stage was 12.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage tomorrow morning to a crest of 25.8 feet early Sunday morning. entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 9 at 2:00PM ChST until March 13 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to 13 ft. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk around Sunday through Tuesday and will be along shores exposed to the northeast and east swell across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher there. Moderate coastal inundation is possible if surf is higher than currently forecasted. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 10:12PM EST until March 10 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
A complex storm system will bring heavy precipitation to the region Sunday. Snow will transition to heavy rain on Sunday morning. Heavy rain falling on already saturated ground will result in localized urban, small stream, and flash flooding. The highest confidence for flooding is along the coast, while the timing on the snow to rain transition will determine the extent of the flood risk northward.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Maine, including the following areas, Androscoggin, Central Interior Cumberland, Coastal Cumberland, Coastal Waldo, Coastal York, Interior Cumberland Highlands, Interior Waldo, Interior York, Kennebec, Knox, Lincoln, Sagadahoc and Southern Somerset and New Hampshire, including the following areas, Belknap, Coastal Rockingham, Eastern Hillsborough, Interior Rockingham, Merrimack, Southern Carroll and Strafford.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Somerset; Interior York; Central Interior Cumberland; Androscoggin; Kennebec; Interior Waldo; Coastal York; Coastal Cumberland; Sagadahoc; Lincoln; Knox; Coastal Waldo; Interior Cumberland Highlands; Southern Carroll; Merrimack; Belknap; Strafford; Eastern Hillsborough; Interior Rockingham; Coastal Rockingham

entry.title: Coastal Flood Watch issued March 8 at 8:53PM EST until March 10 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor to moderate coastal flooding possible. Up to one foot of inundation above ground level is possibly in low-lying areas near shorelines.
* WHERE...Coastal Hancock and Coastal Washington Counties.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Inundation could affect locations such as Deer Isle Causeway, Oak Point Causeway on Deer Isle, Machias, Stonington, Winter Harbor, Bangor, Brewer, Milbridge, Swans Island, South Lubec and Eastport. Breaking waves will cause overtopping of exposed coastal roadways. Areas of concern include but are not limited to, Schoodic Point and Seawall Road. Road debris and minor road damage could close some roadways. Significant beach erosion from previous storms will make erosion prone areas more susceptible to increased erosion. Beach erosion is expected at locations such as Roque Bluffs.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 8 at 3:50PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
A developing moisture band over the North Pacific will stream northeast and into the panhandle starting mid next week, then over the later part of the week it move north through the panhandle with another round of increased rain rates and warming temperatures. Rainfall totals are looking moderate to heavy with 24 hour totals in the 1 to 2 inch range. The main item to watch is a nose of warmer air will move into the panhandle that will push freezing levels over 5000 feet across the southern panhandle and 1000 to 2000 over the north central panhandle.
The item to keep an eye on is additional snow melt from warming along with the rainfall of the heavier rainfall that stream flow will have higher water levels. We will continue to maintain a watch over this potential hazardous situation.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 8 at 2:42PM AKST until March 9 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES HIGHWAY AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS...
.Heavy snow is falling in the Haines and Haines Highway area. Warm, moist air has moved over the Haines and Haines Highway area, transitioning areas near sea level to rain. Snow levels have risen and lie somewhere between 400-600 feet according to nearby surface observations. Areas below 600 ft with heavy, wet snow will have reduced accumulations, but snow will be difficult to manage.
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 5 inches.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 8 at 11:59AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
ESFSEW
A series of storm systems will spread moderate to heavy rainfall across Western Washington this weekend and into early next week. Storm total rainfall amounts of 3 to 6 inches are possible across the Olympic Peninsula. Snow levels near 2500-3000 ft may limit runoff amounts. This amount of prolonged rainfall has the potential to push the Skokomish River into flood stage.
Please monitor the latest river forecasts from the National Weather Service for additional information.

In west central Georgia, Chattahoochee, Coweta, Harris, Heard, Lamar, Macon, Marion, Meriwether, Muscogee, Pike, Schley, Spalding, Stewart, Sumter, Talbot, Taylor, Troup, Upson and Webster.
* WHEN...From 7 PM EST this evening through late Saturday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A storm system will produce moderate to heavy rainfall in the region between Friday night and Saturday night. Rainfall totals of 2 to 5 inches are expected, with locally higher amounts possible. This rainfall combined with saturated soil conditions will likely produce areas of flooding and flash flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 8 at 1:03PM EST until March 10 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Ocean, Somerset, Southeastern Burlington and Western Monmouth and southeast Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Delaware, Eastern Montgomery, Lower Bucks and Philadelphia.
* WHEN...From Saturday afternoon through Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams are running high and may rise out of their banks and could flood with more heavy rain. Flooding may also occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A low pressure system will bring rain, heavy at times, Saturday afternoon through Saturday night. Another 1 to 2 inches of rainfall is forecast within the Flood Watch area in addition to the multiple rounds of rainfall we've already had over the past week. This is likely to bring several river gauges into flood stage across the Passaic, Raritan, and Rancocas basins by Sunday. Urban flooding will also be a threat around the Philadelphia metro area as the heaviest rain moves through late day Saturday into Saturday night. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
